title: Indian Auto Industry Continues To Suffer As Sale Of Vehicles Falls For Successive 11th Month
text:
Indian Auto Industry Continues To Suffer As Sale Of Vehicles Falls For Successive 11th Month

Indian Auto Industry Continues To Suffer As Sale Of Vehicles Falls For Successive 11th Month

Things are not looking bright in the Indian automobile industry, it has not been for some time now. The latest figures are also not promising, as it showed yet another month of the slowdown.

Industry data from the Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers (SIAM) for September showed that passenger vehicle sales plunged by 23.69 percent. During the same time period, commercial vehicle sales were down by 62.11 per cent.

AFP/ REPRESENTATIONAL IMAGE

Passenger vehicle sales dropped to 2,23,317 units in September from 2,92,660 a year ago while passenger car sales dropped by 33.4 percent to 131,281 units compared to the same period in 2018.

Total two-wheeler sales in September declined 22.09 percent to 16,56,774 units compared to 21,26,445 units in the year-ago month.

The industry which has been in turbulence for nearly a year has however pinned its hopes on the upcoming festival season in the country where they are expecting the sales to show some improvement.

In the past few months, several automobile manufacturers had scaled down their production to deal with the slow down.

Thousands of people at various levels also lost their jobs due to the scaling down, which forced the government to step in and announce a reduction in the corporate tax rate to boost manufacturing and lift growth.

Car companies such as Maruti Suzuki India Ltd have lowered prices on some models in an effort to boost sales.

BCCL/ FILE

"We are preparing for best-case and worst-case scenarios ... worst case there will be more production and job cuts," said SIAM president Rajan Wadhera.

The drop in auto sales is also expected to hit earnings for insurance companies such as New India Assurance and ICICI Lombard General Insurance in the September quarter.
